page.title: 05MORE ABOUT OUR BIRDS
page.content: Apart from coniferous woodlands of the Forestry Commission which follow the Dulas Brook and its tributary and which contain generally only woodpigeons and goldcrests as nesting birds, there are a number of mainly small pieces of deciduous woodland which are far richer for birds. This part of mid-Wales is said to carry the greatest breeding density of birds such as the buzzard, pied flycatcher and woodwarbler to be found anywhere in their range. The pied flycatcher is particularly interesting as it is a small migratory bird which returns from Africa each April to the very woodland in which it was reared. They are fond of nesting in boxes provided for them. The redstart and the sandmartin are migrant birds which have only recently started to build up numbers after African drought years.
